englishTranslation: You aren’t going to the party?
vocabIncluded: using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Esa vez, ustedes iban a estar en ese lugar.
englishTranslation: That time, you all were going to be in that place.
vocabIncluded: iban: "were going", "they were going" (Ir, imperfect, 3rd person plural)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
ustedes: "you" plural, subject pronoun (3rd-person plural treatment)

englishTranslation: They are going towards that house.
We were going to be here.
vocabIncluded: using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
íbamos: "were going", "we were going" (Ir, imperfect, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Ibas a ser un buen chico como él.
englishTranslation: You were going to be a good guy like him.
vocabIncluded: ibas: "were going", "you were going" (Ir, imperfect, 2nd person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

englishTranslation: I had done it like that.
vocabIncluded: así: adverb meaning "this way", "that way", "like this", "like that"
había: "had", "I had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 1st person)

englishTranslation: They had done it like her.
vocabIncluded: habían: "had", "they had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 3rd person plural)

englishTranslation: We hadn’t gone by that path.
vocabIncluded: habíamos: "had", "we had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: No lo había hecho, pero lo iba a hacer.
englishTranslation: I hadn’t done it, but I was going to do it.
vocabIncluded: había: "had", "I had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 1st person)
iba: "was going", "I was going" (Ir, imperfect, 1st person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
habías: "had", "you had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 2nd person)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: Para ese día, ella habrá hecho eso.
englishTranslation: By that day, she will have done that.
vocabIncluded: "para": "by" a moment in time, as in "by then"
habrá: "will have", "he/she/it will have" before a participle (Haber, future, 3rd person)

englishTranslation: But she was going to make something.
vocabIncluded: iba: "was going", "he/she/it was going" (Ir, imperfect, 3rd person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Usted no va a ir a *the opera.*
englishTranslation: You(formal) aren’t going to go to the opera.
vocabIncluded: using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
usted: "you", formal subject pronoun, taking 3rd-person treatment

spanishExample: Ustedes no están aquí, por eso vamos al lugar.
englishTranslation: You all aren’t here, that’s why we are going to the place.
vocabIncluded: al: "to the" before a masculine noun
ustedes: "you" plural, subject pronoun (3rd-person plural treatment)

spanishExample: Vamos a hacer lo que *you want* que *we do.*
englishTranslation: We are going to do what you want us to do.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

englishTranslation: They are going to do that badly.
vocabIncluded: using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Vas a hacer lo que te *I’m telling.*
englishTranslation: You’re going to do what I’m telling you.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Ya no voy a ser esa chica.
englishTranslation: I’m not going to be that girl anymore.
vocabIncluded: using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
ya: adverb meaning "anymore", "already", and a variety of other time-related things

spanishExample: Yo voy ese día pero ellas no van.
englishTranslation: I’m going that day but they(f) aren’t going.
